clues: An organization responsible for the allocation of global satellite orbit positions, ensuring non-interference between satellites.
A United Nations specialized agency for information and communication technologies.
Oversees global technical standards to ensure seamless interconnectivity of telecommunication networks.
Asia's largest satellite operator, offering multi-channel pay TV and satellite communications services.
Europe's global navigation satellite system.
First spacecraft to orbit Jupiter, and a famous Italian astronomer.
Canadian-based satellite operator, providing reliable and secure LEO satellite communications solutions.
Canadian satellite operator, aiming high with its LEO satellite constellation for global internet coverage.
Launched in December 1988, this was Europe's first private satellite by SES, setting a precedent in satellite communications.
A satellite launched in partnership with the Luxembourg Government in 2017, providing military and governmental communications.
Launched in October 2021, this Ka-band high-throughput satellite aims to enhance connectivity across the Americas and the Caribbean.
An eHealth platform developed by SES to improve public health in emerging and developing countries, especially in remote areas.
Joint venture between SES and a Middle East satellite operator, announced in 2009, targeting direct-to-home TV services.
Hong Kong-based satellite operator in which SES acquired a significant stake in 1999, marking its initial venture into the Asian market.
Noteworthy for being the first geostationary satellite launched by SpaceX in December 2013, marking a significant partnership.
Appointed as CEO of SES in 2023, bringing a fresh perspective from the telecoms and IT industries.
Leading European company where Al-Saleh gained extensive experience before joining SES.
Company with which SES discussed a potential merger in 2023, highlighting the trend towards industry consolidation.
Partnered with SES in a proposal to the FCC regarding C-band spectrum.
First customer announced by SES for its integrated MEO/LEO solution, aimed at providing connectivity during cruises.
The capacity of a communication channel to transmit data over a specific period, typically measured in bits per second (bps) or hertz (Hz).
The range of frequencies allocated for transmitting data or signals in a communication system.
The transmission path from the ground station to a satellite, used to send data and control commands.
The process of sending data or signals from Earth to a satellite for communication or control purposes.
The transmission path from a satellite to a ground station, used for broadcasting and data reception
The process of sending data or signals from a satellite to Earth.
A device on a satellite that receives, amplifies, and retransmits signals back to Earth, essential for satellite communication
The angular width of the radiation pattern of an antenna, indicating the coverage area.
A measure of the angular spread of electromagnetic radiation emitted or received by an antenna.
The geographical area on the Earth's surface covered by a satellite's signal.
Defines the service area where a satellite's communications signals can be received effectively.
The pattern of signal coverage provided by a satellite antenna or transponder.
The orientation of electromagnetic waves, critical for signal clarity and minimizing interference in satellite communications
The time delay between when a signal is sent and when it is received in satellite communication systems.
The time it takes for data to travel from the transmitting station to the receiving station via the satellite link.
The period of time required for electromagnetic signals to propagate between ground stations and satellites, influenced by the distance traveled and the speed of light.
A measure of the increase in power or intensity of a signal, often used in the context of antennas and amplifiers.
The measure of amplification achieved by an antenna or satellite dish, typically expressed in decibels (dB).
The reduction in signal strength during transmission, often due to distance or interference.
Weakening of electromagnetic signals due to absorption, scattering, or reflection in the transmission medium.
Reduction in the intensity of a signal caused by factors such as distance, obstacles, or interference.
Served as president and CEO of SES from 1995, overseeing its growth into a global satellite industry leader.
Led SES as CEO during pivotal developments, including the launch of the O3b mPOWER satellites and negotiations for a merger with Intelsat.
Media mogul whose Sky TV was among Astra's first major customers, leveraging SES's satellite capabilities for broadcasting.
Aerospace manufacturer responsible for building several of SES's satellites, including parts of the O3b mPOWER constellation.
Aerospace and defense technology company that built the GEOStar-3 satellites, SES-18 and SES-19, for SES.
Defense contractor from which SES acquired DRS Global Enterprise Solutions, enhancing SES Government Solutions' capabilities.
Achieved the first privately funded spacecraft to reach orbit and safely return to Earth.
Partnered with SES for satellite launches from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.
Microsoft's cloud platform that entered a partnership for ground station services, enhancing network operations.
One of the first companies to utilize a hybrid network of MEO and geostationary satellites for cruise connectivity.
An Israeli company tasked with developing modem platforms for a next-gen satellite communications system.
This Israeli company has made significant strides in VSAT (Very Small Aperture Terminal) technology, enhancing global connectivity.
A satellite internet constellation being developed by SpaceX to provide global broadband coverage.
A frequency band in the 26.5-40 GHz range, allowing for high bandwidth data transmission.
A portion of the electromagnetic spectrum between 12 and 18 GHz, commonly employed for satellite TV broadcasting.
A town in Luxembourg, known as a significant hub for satellite and communication technology companies.
Where satellites orbit the Earth at the same rate as the planet's rotation.
Located approximately 35,786 kilometers above the Earth's equator, enabling constant coverage of a specific area.
Located between 2,000 and 35,786 kilometers above the earth, offering lower latency than GEO satellites.
Characterized by an altitude up to 2,000 kilometers above the Earth's surface.
A British satellite telecommunications company, providing global mobile services for maritime, aviation, and land-based users.
British satellite telecommunications company, providing mobile voice and data services to ships, aircraft, and remote land locations.
One was demoted to a dwarf.
We have eight of them in our solar system.
A company that operates a constellation of Earth-imaging satellites, capturing high-resolution images of the earth. Pelican is not a bird to them.
A path followed by a satellite around a celestial body.
An instrument used to observe distant objects, not just for pirates.
Galileo improved this to study the heavens.
One small step for man, one giant leap for one of these.
The maker of tides.
Where Wallace and Gromit went for a cheese picnic.
Earth's nightlight.
The largest planet in our solar system.
Roman god of thunder.
Fifth planet from the Sun.
Earth's hot sister planet.
The god of war.
A rust-colored rock.
The eighth planet from the Sun.
This planet is famous for its spectacular ring system.
A spacecraft that explored Saturn and its moons, and captured stunning images of the ringed planet.
The first artificial satellite launched into space in 1957.
A space telescope that has provided stunning images of the universe, named after an astronomer who discovered the rate of expansion of the universe.
Man-made object orbiting Earth, used for communication and observation.
Sputnik was the first artificial one.
Natural ones include moons orbiting planets.
Unwanted disruption or distortion of electro-magnetic signals.
Newton was famous for formulating the laws governing it.
Requires a pad, a countdown, and a lot of fuel.
Ceres is the largest known one in our solar system.
Celestial bodies orbiting the Sun, often found between Mars and Jupiter.
Ancient Greek philosopher and mathematician, but also a French company.
A titan in defense, space, and security, or an ancient philosopher.
American multinational that designs, manufactures, and sells airplanes, rotorcraft, rockets, and satellites.
One of its airplanes is named after a large bird of prey. Another one had a falling door.
A European multinational aerospace corporation, which manufactures everything from passenger jets to space launch vehicles.
A company specializing in communication satellites, Earth observation systems, and advanced geospatial solutions.
A centerpiece of the modern living room.
A shallow container, typically used for cooking or serving food, or a type of antenna.
A project leading the charge in Europe for secure Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) via a low-earth-orbit satellite, aimed at pioneering next-generation cybersecurity.
Jointly funded by ESA, the EU, and various European countries, this initiative will employ a dedicated satellite and ground network for validating key quantum communications technologies.
This Abu Dhabi-based satellite communications company is a subsidiary of Mubadala Investment Company PJSC, offering services across multiple continents including Europe and Asia.
A leading satellite operator in the Middle East, launched in January 2008, providing secure and reliable satellite communications solutions for government and commercial customers.
Home to Pluto and many other dwarf planets, it shares its name with a 20th-century Dutch astronomer.
Not just a belt, but a project aiming to net the sky.
The world's largest rainforest, or a giant in e-commerce.
Named after female warriors of Greek mythology, it's both a river and a global marketplace.
A company known for its e-commerce platform, cloud services, and ambitious space ventures.
Entrepreneur who took a suborbital spaceflight in July 2021.
He ventured from e-commerce to space.
Blue Origin's bet for heavy-lift capabilities.
Launch vehicle named after the first American to orbit Earth.
NASA program aiming to return humans to the Moon.
NASA program named after Apollo's twin sister.
America's first satellite, launched in 1958.
NASA program that landed humans on the Moon.
NASA rover exploring Mars, that landed in 2012.
The first rover to explore Mars. Landed in 1997.
NASA's Earth observation satellite series.
Next-generation space telescope launched in 2021.
Successor to the Hubble Space Telescope.
Space telescope designed to find Earth-like planets.
Orbiting multinational laboratory.
SpaceX's next-generation spacecraft, designed for Mars' colonization.
SpaceX's fully reusable spacecraft, aiming to revolutionize space travel.
The Final Frontier according to Captain Kirk.
Not just a key on your keyboard, but also the cosmos' vast expanse.
Planet saved from aliens by Will Smith in '96.
Third rock from the sun, not just a '90s sitcom.
The blue marble.
Celestial celebrities.
A massive, luminous sphere of plasma held together by gravity.
They guide sailors.
The invisible thread between Earth and space.
Information's silent messenger.
Data's sudden sprint.
Light's mischievous messenger.
Fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation.
A series of rockets developed by SpaceX for space exploration.
A bird of prey, or a spacecraft designed to soar.
Directly overhead.
Directly underneath.
A band that's final in countdowns.
Multi-orbit and european.
Propulsion system of O3b mPOWER satellites.
US regulatory body for communications.
The U.S. regulator of communications, from airwaves to internet.
It guides our sailors, but it is not a star.
ESA rocket family.
Spectrum range repurposed for 5G mobile broadband services by the FCC.
SES elected to clear a portion of this spectrum in the US for 5G deployment.
Indian telco involved in a joint venture with SES for broadband services.
A major player in the Indian telecommunications market.
Site where SES launched four O3b medium Earth orbit satellites in April 2019.
Location of the CSG, a major spaceport.
SES's satellite system promising high-speed connectivity from medium Earth orbit.
Munich-based provider of music and travel channels via Astra 19.2Â°E satellites.
Mobile network operator in Kazakhstan partnering with SES for connectivity solutions.
Kazakhstani operator showcasing reliable video calling and streaming services with SES.
A major american player in telecommunications, partnering with SES for spectrum allocation.
European mobile network operator exploring partnerships with SES for enhanced services.
French telecommunications company exploring satellite partnerships with SES.
